florian.kuhlmann wrote:
> Hello,
> 
> is it possible to write SURTs directly in the seeds.txt? I use the
> DecidingScope along with the SurtPrefixedDecideRule. 
> I tried to mix both URIs and SURTs, the SURTs get parsed out with the
> following message:
> 
> "Some items in seed specification were ignored. This may not indicate
> any problem, but the ignored items are displayed here for reference:"

It is possible to include SURT prefixes as directives in the seeds file, 
by prefixing them with '+'. However, this only serves to *add* more 
acceptable prefixes -- it does not further restrict what can be crawled.

The above message is generated by the code which looks for plain seeds; 
a second pass over the seeds file extracts the SURT prefix directives. 
Hence, the equivocation: 'may not indicate any problem'.

> So is it only possible to submit SURTs over a local surt-prefix-file
> (you cant submit it in a jar via jmx, right)? 

Per our JMX lead St.Ack, currently the only parts of a JAR file 
submitted as a job to run that are locally exploded (and thus available 
for addressing via relative paths) are the order.xml, seeds.txt, and 
'settings/' directories. So it might work if you took the nonstandard 
approach of putting your surt-prefix-file inside the 'settings/' 
directory and adjusted the path accordingly, but it'd be safer for now 
to drop the file local to the crawler via other channels.

> I need own defined SURTs because i don't want heritrix to crawl the
> leading path of a given URI if the URI is pointing to a concrete
> document(e.g. if i submit
> "http://www.example.com/example/example.html", i only want heritrix to
> get  the document "example.html" and not crawl
> "http://www.example.com/example/"; otherwise, if i only submit
> "http://www.example.com/example/", i want heritrix to crawl down from
> that path). It seems that this behavior is impossible to implement
> using the existing scopes and rules. Switching of heritrix automatic
> surt building and defining SURTs only if i have a path seems the only
> way for me to achieve the wanted behavior, or is there an easier way?

You are right that the Heritrix process for automatically deducing SURT 
prefixes from seeds is working against your goal. The common case in our 
experience has been that 'sibling' pages for 'example.html' with the 
same preceding path are wanted along with 'example.html', so the 
auto-configuration deduced from seeds implements that.

Depending on your other priorities, there are a number of ways to crawl 
"http://www.example.com/example/example.html" without ruling other 
"http://www.example.com/example/*" URIs in scope.

At the very least, if using a SurtPrefixedDecideRule, you want to turn 
off the default ""seeds-as-surt-prefixes" setting, so that the 
auto-inclusion of the '/example/'-trunacted prefix doesn't occur.

Then, some alternative options would be:
- Disable/remove the 'Preselector'. Then, seeds won't be checked against 
scope before being crawled, and any seed URI you supply will be crawled 
regardless of your other scope configuration.
- Add a 'SeedAcceptDecideRule' to ensure that seeds are automatically 
ruled-in.
- Change the crawl to something more broad -- perhaps beginning the 
rules with an AcceptDecideRule then knocking out URIs you don't want, in 
contrast to the default 'reject all then start ruling things in' 
approach. An accept-all which then rejects URIs more than 0 hops from 
seeds essentially means "only crawl seeds", though often a late 
TransclusionDecideRule is also added ato go 1 or more hops as necessary 
to get inline/embedded resources.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
